question: [File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [Deserialization attack] Does the bcs::from_bytes() call validate the structure and size of PREBUILT_BUNDLE_BYTES before deserialization, or can a malicious .mpb file with crafted BCS data cause memory exhaustion, infinite loops, or stack overflow during deserialization? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [Type confusion] Can an attacker replace the prebuilt.mpb file with a binary blob that deserializes to a PrebuiltPackagesBundle with malformed type signatures, causing type confusion when modules are later loaded into the Move VM and potentially bypassing type safety checks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-24] [Panic-based DoS] Does the .expect() on line 24 mean that any deserialization failure causes a panic during lazy initialization, and can an attacker deliberately corrupt the prebuilt.mpb file to cause permanent application crashes whenever PreBuiltPackagesImpl is first accessed? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [Integer overflow] Does BCS deserialization check for integer overflow when parsing length prefixes in the PrebuiltPackagesBundle structure, or can a malicious .mpb file with crafted length fields cause integer overflow leading to buffer overruns or incorrect memory allocation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [Recursive bomb] Can a malicious PrebuiltPackagesBundle contain deeply nested BTreeMap structures that cause stack overflow during BCS deserialization, exploiting the lack of depth limits in the deserializer? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 16-17] [Size validation] Does include_bytes!() impose any size limit on the prebuilt.mpb file, or can an attacker provide an arbitrarily large binary blob that exhausts memory during compilation or runtime deserialization? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [Checksum bypass] Is there any integrity check (checksum, hash, signature) on PREBUILT_BUNDLE_BYTES before deserialization to detect corruption or tampering, or does the code blindly trust the binary data loaded at compile time? [File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [Version mismatch] Does BCS deserialization validate that the PrebuiltPackagesBundle format version matches the expected version, or can an old/incompatible .mpb file from a different Aptos version cause undefined behavior or security vulnerabilities when deserialized? [File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [Malicious BTreeMap] Can a PrebuiltPackagesBundle with duplicate keys in the BTreeMap<String, PrebuiltPackage> cause unexpected behavior during deserialization, potentially allowing package shadowing or overwriting? [File: aptos-core/crates/transaction-workloads-lib/src/prebuilt_packages.rs] [Line: 23-25] [UTF-8 validation] Does BCS deserialization validate that package names (BTreeMap keys) are valid UTF-8 strings without control characters or malicious Unicode sequences that could cause issues in logging, display, or further processing?
